subject: RE: [junit] JUnit Testing Code That Has System.exit(n);
msgSnippet: Sounds to me like you need a mock System object that has an exit(n) method, and a way to inject that mock System object into the classes that use it.  Do you
messageBody:
Sounds to me like you need a mock System object that has an exit(n)
method, and a way to inject that mock System object into the classes
that use it. Do you know what I mean by "mock object"? If not, that
would be a good place to start Googling.


Todd.


> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Bob Russell
> Sent: Thursday, September 07, 2006 3:28 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] JUnit Testing Code That Has System.exit(n);
>
>
> I'm involved on a project as the QA. To improve my
> development skills and my JUnit skills, I am writing some
> JUnit tests. Today, I found that the developer had
> implemented System.exit(n) throughout the application
> whenever there was a trapped exception.
>
> Now, the requirements call for the application to return some
> exit code telling any downstream processes whether this
> application was 100% successful with no warnings (rc=0), 100%
> successful with warnings (rc=4), not successful at all
> (rc=8). However, the only java mechanism for reporting
> return codes is System.exit(n), based on my use of Google.
>
> My JUnit dilemma then, is that System.exit(n) gives the
> required application behavior but doesn't seem to be good for
> running JUnit tests from a test suite since System.exit(n)
> ends the JVM.
>
> Does anyone have any insights they can share? Since this is
> my first post to this forum, I'm happy to Google some more if
> you'll only give me some keyword hint(s) beyond what I've
> already tried: "java exit code".
>
> Thanks!
